When does the blind spot on the retina become significant for a pilot?

options.text: If aonther aircraft is on a converging course and the pilots field of view is restricted on one side, the pilot might fail to see the other aircraft if it is positioned in the blind spot of the unobstructed eye.
If the pilots vision is unrestricted and focused directly ahead, in conditions of low forward visibility, the converging aircraft may go undetected if it falls on the blind spot.
When flying in conditions of low forward visibility, the existence of the blind spot on the retina of each eye can make the judgement of the distance of other traffic more difficult for the pilot.
When an aircraft is approaching from head on it will disappear for a moment as it passes the blind spot on the retina. It will remain undetected until the relative position of the aircraft changes.

Contact lenses can easily become fogged when entering warm, moist spaces coming from the cold.
Adequate correction is provided only for the very central area of the field of vision.

variant.question:
On a tropical flight, the pilot should use/wear:1. Sunscreen to protect you from the strong sun 
 2. Sunglasses which filter infrared light 
 3. Dark, long, tight-fit clothes to keep off mosquitoes 
 4. A straw hat to protect your head from the sun
A possible problem associated with contact lenses is:

options.text: the eyes can become too dry.
highly decreased visibility in conditions with weak illumination.
they need to be cleaned several times during a day.
colours can appear differently, therefore contact lenses are allowed for VFR flights during the day only.

variant.question: The time needed for an eye to adjust to bright light is:

Glaucoma is characterized by:
1) disturbed light adaptation
2) progressive narrowing of the visual field
3) insidious onset and concealed progression
4) an increase in intra-ocular pressure
What does not impair the function of the photosensitive cells?
What type of sunglasses should you avoid wearing whilst flying?
